When initials collide (II)

A random exploration of first and family name initials

statistics
fun
EN
All letters are equal, but some letters are more equal than others
Author

Guido Huyberechts

Published

October 23, 2024

Modified

January 15, 2025

Introduction

In the first post in this series I modified the code by Antoine Soetewey (“AS”) from Stats and R1 a bit to allow the probability of the first letters of a first and a family name to deviate from 1/26. So instead of a uniform random distribution of letters, it is now possible to take into account the frequency of these letters as they occur in real life populations.

Such population could be the personnel working in a company, eventually extended with other company lists from customers or suppliers involved in a project. Or whatever.

For this excercise I use a set of data available from Statbel. Statbel, the Belgian statistical office, collects, produces and disseminates reliable and relevant figures on the Belgian economy, society and territory. And it has data on the occurence of first and family names in Belgium2. I use the 2024 data (status of 2024-01-01). Note that it is not a complete list (only the top 10 000 family names are reported and first names with less than 5 counts are omitted). But it will serve the purpose.

Let’s start with the first names.

First names

Exploration of the population

The data for first names are available as an Excel file3 and it contains two sheets, namely for male and female first names. Furthermore the counts, apart from the totals, are split according to the different regions in Belgium (Flemish region, Walloon region and Brussels capital region). Within the regions age is also taken into account ([,18[, [18,64],[65,[). For now, we don’t care about age (although when compared over time it would probably give a nice trend of popular names).

When I take the first 15 first names for each region, the following table emerges.

Remember that the first names with less than five occurences have been omitted from the list, for each region. Nevertheless this means that for Belgium there are 25085 unique male first names in the list. For the different regions this is 17132, 9194 and 7669 for respectively Flanders, Wallonia and Brussels.

A similar table can be constructed for the female part of the population.

This means that for Belgium there are 29210 unique female first names in the list. For the different regions this is 19961, 11068 and 8612 for respectively Flanders, Wallonia and Brussels.

Even from this small sample it can be concluded that some names are quite popular in all three regions, but some are also quite popular only in specific regions.

Dealing with initials

As we are interested in the initials only, we will count only the first letters. So all Marie, Maria, Monique, … will end up in the M-bin on female side. Marc, Mohamed, Mohammed, Michel, … will be placed in the M-bin on the male side. But as we do not discriminate in our team, we combine both M-bins (and all others) letter-wise. Same for all Jean-Paul, Jean-Philippe, Jean-Bernard, Jean-Pierre, …, all ending up in the J-bin.

First letters encountered in first names
Female first names
A Á Â Å B C Ç D e E
É È F G H I Í J K L
M N O Ö p P Q R S T
U Ü V W X Y Z - - -
Male first names

L M N O Ó Ô Ö P Q R
S t T U Ú Ü V W X Y
Z - - - - - - - - -
Source: GHUY

Now, surprise, if we count the number of first letters for the male and female population, we end up with 41 and 37 respectively. Another call for looking deeper into the data, even when we are talking about millions of persons. It turns out that some names do not start with capital letters and others carry accents or umlauts. So a procedure to handle these is needed. We replace all “weird” letters by the closest “normal” capitalized letters.

Conclusion: not all letters are created equal when it comes to being used as first letters for females, nor males. And the frequency can differ quite a lot between letters. We have also included a vertical red line at 3.85 %, the percentage that would be obtained when all letters were distributed equally over all first names.

Probability distribution

So now we know how many people carry a first name with a given letter and we can compare the outcome of the team construction question from the previous post with a “real” distribution (as far as we can consider building a team of eight persons starting from the complete Belgian population real of course).

As we do not discriminate for our team membership, we merge the datasets for females and males and calculate the (discrete) distribution of first letters over the complete population.

As is clear in Figure 2, the distribution is no longer uniform. The dashed horizontal line depicts the fraction of the population with the corresponding first letter of the first name in the case of where all letters would have equal probabality. Not so in reality, with M is a winner, thanks to every Marie, Maria, Martine, Monique, Mohammed, Mohamed, Marc, and all other M*’s in this country.

In Figure 3 we show the (discrete) cumulative function. The concept for our simulation is clear: if we now draw a uniformily distributed random number between 0 and 1, say 0.625 (red line), we can see that our team member would have a first name starting with M when taken from the country’s population, instead of Q if all letters would have equal probabilities.

We are halfway, we have the means to determine the first letter of our two-letter initials. Let’s now focus on the family names.

Family names

Exploration of the population

The data for family names are also available as an Excel file4 and this one contains only one sheet. Taking into account ex eaquo counts, we have a list of 1055 family names.

When I take the 100 most common family names, we obtain the following table.

A simple look at the above table already suggests large differences the number of people carying different family names. Near the bottom of the list, around position 10000, families with about 200 members are encountered. Quite a difference with the Peeters and Janssens families. We also see that probably D and V will be pretty common letters at the beginning of a family name.

First letters encountered in family names
a A B C Ç d D e E F
G H I J K L M N O Ö
P Q R S T U Ü v V W
X Y Z - - - - - - -
Source: GHUY

We again observe some weird characters as starting letters and replace them as we have done before for the first names. We also note that, despite we are dealing with the top 10000 family names, these represent only 6360590 persons, so we need at least 25000 more family names to cover the whole population …

Again the results show that the probability is not equally distributed over the letters as Figure 4 clearly illustrates. With the first letters of both first names and family names showing a non-uniform distribution, it is normal that we expect that the two-letter initials are not equally distributed as well. Remember that each of the 676 combinations of two letters previously had an equal probability of 0.148 %.

The (discrete) cumulative function for the first letters of family names is shown if Figure 5. As for the first names we can draw a horizontal red line at 0.625 (as an example of a uniformily distributed random number between 0 and 1). Our team member, taken from the country’s population, would have a family name starting with N. With equal probabilities probabilities for all letters, we would of course end up with a Q as starting letter.

So far for the letters of first and family names, that’s it for now. Let’s combine the letters to two-letter initials in the next post.
